    Acetylene Group, Friend or Foe in Medicinal Chemistry

    • Tanaji T. Talele*
      Tanaji T. Talele
      Department of Pharmaceutical Sciences, College of Pharmacy and Health Sciences, St. John’s University, Queens, New York 11439, United States
      *Phone: (718)990-5405. Fax: (718)990-1877. Email: [email protected]
      More by Tanaji T. Talele
      View Biography
      http://orcid.org/0000-0002-5938-6505
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2020, 63, 11, 5625–5663
    Publication Date (Web):February 7, 2020

    Publication History

    • Published online7 February 2020
    • Published inissue 11 June 2020
    https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.jmedchem.9b01617

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    The use of an acetylene (ethynyl) group in medicinal chemistry coincides with the launch of the Journal of Medicinal Chemistry in 1959. Since then, the acetylene group has been broadly exploited in drug discovery and development. As a result, it has become recognized as a privileged structural feature for targeting a wide range of therapeutic target proteins, including MAO, tyrosine kinases, BACE1, steroid receptors, mGlu5 receptors, FFA1/GPR40, and HIV-1 RT. Furthermore, a terminal alkyne functionality is frequently introduced in chemical biology probes as a click handle to identify molecular targets and to assess target engagement. This Perspective is divided into three parts encompassing: (1) the physicochemical properties of the ethynyl group, (2) the advantages and disadvantages of the ethynyl group in medicinal chemistry, and (3) the impact of the ethynyl group on chemical biology approaches.

    Physicochemical Properties of the Ethynyl Group

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Acetylene, discovered in 1836 by Edmund Davy, is a colorless and odorless gas. It is comprised of a carbon–carbon triple bond that features one σ- and two π-bonds. The triple bond of an acetylene is shorter (1.21 Å) and stronger than a carbon–carbon (C–C) double (1.34 Å) or single (1.53 Å) bond. For example, 318 kJ/mol is required to break a π bond of acetylene as compared to the ethylene bond, which requires 268 kJ/mol.(1,2) Because of its increased S character, the acetylene −C–H bond is shorter (1.06 Å) than that of either ethene (1.08 Å) or ethane (1.09 Å), respectively.(3) The acetylene group is stabilized via hyperconjugation (π bonds overlap with neighboring C–H bonds) when it carries an alkyl substituent. Therefore, internal alkynes are more stable than terminal ones. A terminal alkyne is a stronger Brönsted acid (pKa ∼ 25) compared to the corresponding alkene (pKa ∼ 44) or alkane (pKa ∼ 50). Moreover, the acetylene serves as a proton donor because it is a weak electron-withdrawing group.(3,4) The H–C–C angle in an acetylene group is linear (i.e., 180°), thus, it can serve as a rigid spacer that places any appendage in the plane of the acetylene group. An acetylene group π-system provides donor–acceptor interactions similar to those observed with the phenyl ring,(5,6) and thus, it can also function as an effective isostere of the phenyl moiety.
    Although an acetylene is a hydrocarbon, it is considered a functional group because its −C–H can be deprotonated under basic conditions to produce a conjugate base (acetylide ion). Similarly, it can undergo nucleophilic addition at the electrophilic π bonds. Consequently, an acetylene group has a prominent place in the synthesis of many groups, including alkanes, alkenes, aldehydes, halides, heterocycles, and in ring-closing metathesis.(7) A copper-catalyzed azide–alkyne [3 + 2] cycloaddition (CuAAC), the so-called “click reaction”, rapidly produces 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazoles. This reaction has been broadly explored for efficient lead optimization in medicinal chemistry.(8,9) CuAAC click chemistry has also positively influenced peptide-based drug design.(10) The acetylene also serves as a notable building block for chemical biology research (therapeutic target identification/validation) due to its efficient conversion to the 1,2,3-triazole ring via a 1,3-dipolar CuAAC click reaction with azide reagents.(11)
    It is evident that the acetylene group has been important in medicinal chemistry by the fact that it was utilized in pharmacologically active compounds as early as the launch of the Journal of Medicinal Chemistry in 1959.(12−15) The continued widespread popularity of this functional group in medicinal chemistry is also apparent from the number of examples of approved drugs or those in clinical/preclinical evaluation that containing a terminal or an internal acetylene group. There are many roles that this structural feature can play in drug activity, which include potency enhancement (by a complementary fit into a receptor binding pocket), reactive warhead (for irreversible inhibition of a target protein), nonpolar linear rigid spacer (to direct pharmacophore appendages in a favorable geometry), bioisostere to a wide range of functionalities (i.e., cyano, chloro, iodo, carboxamide, ethene, carbonyl, ethyl, phenyl, and cyclopropyl groups), and modulation of drug metabolism pharmacokinetic (DMPK) profile.
    An ethyne group also can be considered a privileged structural pharmacophore, for example, in the development of free fatty acid receptor 1 agonists(16−18) and mGlu5 receptor allosteric modulators.(19−21) However, it should be noted that a terminal acetylene group possesses certain inherent context-dependent liabilities such as irreversible inhibition of drug metabolizing enzymes (CYP450s,(22−26) glutathione (GSH)/glutathione-S-transferases (GSTs),(27) and UDP-glucuronyl transferases (UDPGTs)).(28)
    Where possible, matched molecular pairs (MMPs) with succinct discussion will be provided for the reader with references to the original scientific literature for a more detailed information. In this Perspective, an acetylene group will be presented with context-dependent bilateral features, playing as a friend or a foe depending on the molecular or biological circumstances. It is hoped that this Perspective will also demonstrate that the positive contributions of an acetylene group outweigh its potential liabilities in the medicinal chemistry research to reinforce its utility for medicinal chemists.

    The Good Sides of the Ethynyl Group in Medicinal Chemistry

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    The Ethynyl Group is a Versatile Isostere of a Wide Range of Groups (i.e., Chloro, Cyano, Iodo, Ethyl, Ethene, Carbonyl, Carboxamide, Phenyl, and Cyclopropyl)

    The ethynyl group is a nonclassical bioisostere based on its versatility. For example, its π cloud effectively mimics aromatic rings and its polarized −CH motif acts as a weak hydrogen bond donor and thus can be isosterically replaced with the iodine atom. Furthermore, molecular electrostatic potentials for the chloro-, bromo-, and iodo-benzenes are similar to those observed for the phenylacetylene. The ethynyl group is a bioisostere of the iodine atom based on their comparable length. Further, the weak hydrogen bonding capacity of an acetylene is parallel in strength to that of a halogen bond. A prominent use of this isosteric replacement is facilitated by the fact that the iodine atom on an aromatic ring can be conveniently displaced using Sonogashira coupling chemistry.(29) The presence of similar π system and donor–acceptor interactions in an acetylene, ethene, and phenyl allows them to serve as isosteres of each other.
    Both the cyano and the acetylene groups share structural similarity as evidenced from the presence of a sterically less demanding (suitable for exploiting sterically congested target protein active site environments) short and polarized linear triple bonds due to the presence of sp-hybridized centers. Further sp-hybridized terminal carbon in an acetylene has an electronegativity of 3.29, whereas sp-hybridized nitrogen in cyano group has an electronegativity of 5.07, suggesting that both are electron-withdrawing groups although the cyano is more powerful electron-withdrawing compared to an acetylene.(30) Therefore, an acetylene and the cyano groups are isosterically interchanged in bioactive compounds. Functional mimicry of an acetylene group extends to the trans-carboxamide, carbonyl, ethyl, and cyclopropyl groups as evidenced through examples provided in this Perspective.

    Mtb PknA/PknB Dual Inhibitors 1 and 2

    Protein kinase A (PknA) and protein kinase B (PknB) of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) are attractive drug targets due to their essential role in the bacterial cell growth.(31,32) Wang and colleagues decided to develop novel inhibitors that target both kinases to obtain potent inhibitors with a possibility of lowering frequency of drug resistance.(33) Toward this goal, they developed an early lead compound 1 that demonstrated single-digit micromolar minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) against Mtb and also showed single-digit nanomolar potency against both kinases (Figure 1). However, 1 suffered from poor selectivity over mammalian kinase CDK2. In the meanwhile, they obtained the X-ray crystal structure of 1 bound to PknA and PknB. These structural studies revealed the presence of a pocket due to flipped glycine residues (Gly100 in PknA and Gly97 in PknB), which could be exploited to achieve selectivity toward Mtb kinases over mammalian kinase CDK2. Accordingly, they replaced a 5-chloro group with a 5-ethynyl group as in compound 2, a change that resulted in retention of potency against Mtb kinases as well as in antibacterial activity against Mtb and, most importantly, improved selectivity toward Mtb kinases over CDK2.

    Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2 (EGFR2) Inhibitors Gefitinib (3) and Erlotinib (4)

    The chlorine atom in 3 forms a weak halogen bonding interaction(34) with the backbone carbonyl oxygen atom of Leu788 within the active site of EGFR2.(35) Both the aromatic C–Cl and aryl-C≡CH show a positive charge at the tip of these groups.(36) Because an acetylene group presents a polarized −CH moiety that can serve as a weak hydrogen bond donor, it successfully imitates the chlorine atom of 3 to obtain 4 (Figure 2) as substantiated from its cocrystal structure with EGFR2.(37)

    Fast Skeletal Muscle Troponin Activators 5–8

    Myosin and troponin are the two major components of fast skeletal muscle fibers. The troponin complex localized in the thin filament along with actin and tropomyosin play a key role in calcium sensing.(38) Patients with compromised muscle function are expected to benefit from the troponin activators.(39,40) Consequently, Collibee and colleagues decided to develop small-molecule troponin activators.(41) Structure–activity relationship (SAR) studies around the imidazopyrazine scaffold at the R-position led to a chloro derivative 5 with a submicromolar potency. Replacement of the compact electron-withdrawing chlorine atom with the cyano group resulted in compound 6 with a substantial loss of potency. While replacement with a vinyl substituent gave the potent compound 7, one with an alkyne substituent as in 8 (tirasemtiv, CK-2017357)(41) led to the most potent compound (Figure 3). Compared to 5, compound 8 showed improved clearance and unbound fraction in rat PK studies. Compound 8 is currently undergoing phase 3 clinical trial to evaluate its effect on respiratory function in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (NCT02496767).(42)

    Cyanoenone Michael Acceptors as Anti-inflammatory Agents 9–12

    Zheng and colleagues converted the complex tricyclic cyanoenone 9 into simplified Michael acceptors in the form of monocyclic cyanoenones 10–12 possessing anti-inflammatory action (Figure 4).(43) The study indicated a progressive increase in potency when going from a cyano to an ethene to an ethyne substitution at the C3-position. These compounds target cysteine residues of the target proteins such as Keap1 in a reversible manner.

    Pan-Serotype Dengue Virus NS5 RNA-Dependent RNA Polymerase Inhibitors 13–16

    Functional activity of the dengue virus (DENV) NS5 RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp) is essential for the replication of dengue virus. It has no mammalian counterpart, thus making it an attractive target for the development of novel agents to treat dengue viral infections. Yokokawa and colleagues decided to optimize fragment-based early leads to obtain compound 13 that showed good potency (Figure 5).(44) The X-ray crystal structure of 13 bound to the NS5 RdRp domain revealed that the C2-position of a thiophene ring offered the desired vector to extend the compound into the narrow cavity. The same structural data also indicated the presence of a water molecule in the narrow cavity forming hydrogen bonding interactions with His800 and Gln802. Therefore, they introduced a cyano group at the C2-position of the thiophene ring (compound 14) to form an interaction network with the bound water molecule, but unfortunately with a considerable loss of potency. Next, they opted to displace the bound water molecule by installing a propargyl alcohol group. These efforts led to the identification of compound 15 showing a greater potency than 14. The X-ray crystal structure of 15 bound to the NS5 RdRp domain confirmed the binding of a propargyl alcohol moiety in the narrow cavity where it has successfully displaced the water molecule while forming hydrogen bonds, with the backbone of His800 and the side chain of Gln802. Compound 15 showed pan-serotype (DENV1–4) activity, with IC50 values ranging from 0.3–2.2 μM. Further optimization of 15 ultimately led to compound 16, showing enhanced potency in biochemical and cell-based assays.

    Phosphoinositide-3-Kinase (PI3K)-γ Inhibitors 17–19

    Because PI3K-γ signaling is critical for the function of myeloid cells, it serves as an important immuno-oncology target.(45) To obtain potent and selective PI3K-γ inhibitors, Evans and co-workers introduced a cyano group at the C8-position of the isoquinolinone scaffold to obtain 17, showing a moderate potency and a greater selectivity toward PI3K-γ than toward PI3K-δ (Figure 6).(46) Isosteric replacement of the cyano group with an acetylene gave 18 with improved potency and selectivity. Because the acetylene CH pointed toward a nonconserved pocket, it was substituted with an N-methylpyrazol-4-yl moiety to obtain clinical candidate 19 (IPI-549)(46) with considerable selectivity toward PI3K-γ over PI3K-δ.

    HIV-1 Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitor (4′-Ethynylstavudine/22)

    Because the C4′-position tolerates an sp-hybridized carbon atom for binding to the active site of HIV-1 reverse transcriptase (HIV-1 RT), Tanaka and co-workers decided to replace the C4′-H of 20 with a cyano group (Figure 7).(47) This modification led to 21 with no improvement in anti-HIV activity compared to 20. However, introduction of an alternate sp-hybridized group such as ethynyl gave 22 with submicromolar anti-HIV activity and lower toxicity toward mammalian cells. Because compound 22 must undergo phosphorylation by thymidine kinase to form an active triphosphate metabolite, the Km value was determined. The Km value of 22 toward human thymidine kinase was lower than that of the parent molecule 20, thus undergoing a faster conversion than 20.

    First-in-Class Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Translocation Inhibitor (NRTTI) (23, MK8591, EFdA/Islatravir)

    EFdA is a highly potent nucleoside HIV-1 reverse transcriptase translocation inhibitor, also known as 4′-ethynyl-2-fluoro-2′-deoxyadenosine (23, Figure 8).(48,49) Compound 23 showed anti-HIV efficacy in primary cells at subnanomolar concentrations.(48,50) It has been shown to maintain activity against both wild-type and various drug-resistant HIV-1 RT mutants.(48) The 4′-ethynyl and 2-fluoro groups in 23 contributed toward increased selectivity (CC50/IC50 > 60000) in early stage antiviral investigation.(48) The X-ray crystal structure of 23 with HIV-1 RT revealed strong van der Waals interactions of the 4′-ethynyl moiety with a preformed hydrophobic pocket comprised of residues Ala114, Tyr115, Phe160, and Met184 and the methylene portion of Asp185.(51) These strong interactions allows 23 to sit tightly at the pretranslocation binding mode (N-site) and thus prevent binding of an incoming dNTP, which ultimately leads to a termination of DNA polymerization.(51) Compound 23 is currently being investigated in a phase 2 clinical trial for the treatment of HIV-1 infection (NCT03272347).

    GPR40 Agonists 24 and 25

    GPR40 (free fatty acid reporter 1, FFA1) activation has shown the ability to stimulate the secretion of insulin only when glucose levels are elevated.(52) Thus, it can serve as antidiabetic drug target. Li and colleagues began the development of GPR40 agonists based on an arylpropanoic acid scaffold.(53) Among the many analogues synthesized, analogues 24 and 25 demonstrated isosterism between the propyne and cyano groups (Figure 9). From a comparison of agonistic potency, the propynyl moiety is interchangeable with the cyano group. Although the cyano derivative was marginally more potent than the propynyl analogue, it was chemically unstable; therefore, further structure optimization efforts retained the propynyl moiety at the β-position of the thienylpropanoic acid scaffold.

    Quinazolinones as Anti-MRSA Agents

    Replacement of the cyano group in compound 26 with an acetylene as in 27 led to a 67-fold enhanced potency against MRSA strain and an acceptable elimination half-life in mice (Figure 10).(54)

    Thienopyrimidinones as Anti-Clostridium difficile Agents

    We have recently conducted screening of in-house compounds against two pathogenic strains of Clostridium difficile and identified a screening hit, which was optimized to obtain the cyano derivative 28 with a moderate potency. Replacing the cyano group with an acetylene group resulted in 29 with a 16–32-fold increased potency (Figure 11).(55)

    Propargyl-Containing β-Site Amyloid Precursor Protein Cleaving Enzyme 1 (BACE1) Inhibitors 30–36

    BACE1 emerged as a promising target for the discovery of disease-modifying anti-Alzheimer’s therapeutics. Consequently, several BACE1 inhibitors were designed by inserting a privileged propargyl moiety. Fragment-based lead generation and subsequent scaffold hopping led to the 5-cyano-3-pyridinyl-containing aminoisoindole derivative 30 as an early lead compound. Although 30 was a potent inhibitor of BACE1 in the FRET and cell-based assays, it exhibited a very high efflux ratio and a poor permeability in Caco-2 cells. To address these liabilities, the cyano group of 30 was isosterically replaced with a propargyl moiety and thus yielded 31 with increased potency and Caco-2 permeability and reduced efflux ratio (Figure 12). Further the propargyl moiety extends toward the S3 subpocket of the enzyme and displaced a bound water molecule to gain binding affinity.(56)
    Cumming and colleagues(57) synthesized an iminohydantoin scaffold to obtain the S3 pocket binding chlorophenyl substituted iminohydantoin analogue 32 with appreciable biochemical and cell-based potency. To exploit the available space within the S3 subpocket of BACE1, the distal chlorophenyl ring was replaced with the propynylpyridinyl ring to obtain 33 with improved BACE1 and cell Aβ40-based inhibitory potencies (Figure 12).
    Stamford and co-workers(58) optimized a six-membered iminopyrimidinone core, which resulted in the cyanophenyl derivative 34 with nanomolar biochemical and cell-based potency. On the basis of the above principle, they replaced the S3 subpocket-binding 3-cyanophenyl moiety with the 3-propynylpyridinyl moiety to obtain 35 with improved potencies compared to 34. Further gain in potency was achieved by replacing the thiophene ring attachment sites and by the addition of a chlorine atom as evidenced from compound 36 (Figure 12).

    Cytotoxic Compounds 37–39 for Myeloid Malignancies

    Amdouni and co-workers(59) began optimization of their early lead compound 37 (acadesine)(60) that showed poor cytotoxic effect on the chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) K562 cell line, but interestingly, it showed an autophagic mechanism of cell death. Therefore, they replaced the imidazole ring of 37 with a synthetically accessible 1,2,3-triazole ring and obtained compound 38 with moderate inhibitory activity toward K562 cell line. Replacement of the iodine atom in 38 with an isosteric alkynyl substituent capped with an ethyl ester led to 39 with substantially increased cytotoxic effect on K562 cell line (Figure 13). Further compound 39 was able to kill resistant as well as sensitive K562 cells with equal efficiency as evidenced from an IC50 of 0.37 μM.

    HDM2–p53 Interaction Antagonists 40 and 41

    The disruption of interactions between p53 and HDM2 has long been considered a strategy for the development of cancer therapeutics.(61) Parks and co-workers developed a new series of 1,4-benzodiazepine-2,5-diones (BDPs) as antagonists of the p53–HDM2 interaction.(62) Early lead compound 40 featuring the iodine atom at the C7-position of the BDP showed submicromolar activity (Figure 14). Replacement of the iodine atom with an acetylene group led to compound 41 with retention of submicromolar activity. Although acetylene group is smaller in volume compared to the iodine atom, the vector of the acetylene moiety allowed it to fill a hydrophobic region created by binding site residue Phe19 similar to that occupied by the iodine atom.

    D2/D3 Full Agonist 42 to D2 Partial Agonist 43

    Because progressive loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta is the hallmark of Parkinson’s disease, the development of D2/D3 receptor agonists serves as a useful approach to treat Parkinson’s disease. Consequently, Das and co-workers chose to develop a set of D2/D3 full agonists and D2/D3 partial agonists.(63) A full D2/D3 receptor agonist 42 was transformed into a new analogue 43 with partial agonist activity toward D2 but full agonist activity toward D3 by replacing the N-propyl substituent with the N-propargyl group (Figure 15).

    MDR in Cancer Treatment

    Multidrug resistance (MDR) is a common occurrence among all malignancies. Therefore, new agents that can evade MDR are necessary to attain optimal treatment. Toward this objective, Aridoss and co-workers synthesized chromene-based compounds against MDR in cancers.(64) For example, diethyl ester analogue 44 showed micromolar inhibition of HL60 cell growth. Replacing one of the ethyl ester groups with a propargyl ester led to 45 with a >2-fold increased potency. Finally, dipropargyl ester derivative 46 was identified as a submicromolar inhibitor of HL60 cells (Figure 16).

    Discovery of Cysteinyl Leukotriene (CysLT1 and CysLT2) Receptor Antagonist 49 (Gemilukast)

    The cysteinyl leukotriene (CysLT1 and CysLT2) receptors are expressed on airway smooth muscle and inflammatory cells, and thus antagonizing these receptors is an attractive strategy for treating asthma.(65,66) Itadani and co-workers began optimization of the 2-methylindole-1-acetic acid lead compound 47 that exhibited low permeability (Figure 17).(67) They postulated poor permeability of 47 is a result of conformational flexibility and acidic property. This prompted them to replace the trans-double bond with a more linear triple bond, leading to 48 with a retention of dual antagonist activity of 47. Having established successful replacement of the trans-double bond with a linear triple bond, they conducted further modifications (i.e., the indole-N-acetic acid to indole-N-butanoic acid, chloro to fluoro exchange, and insertion of a fluorine at C4 of the indole ring) in 48, which led to the discovery of 49 (gemilukast).

    Bis-Michael Acceptors 50–52 as Chemical Probes for Keap1/Nrf2/ARE Pathways

    Kelch-like ECH-associated protein 1 (Keap1)/nuclear factor erythroid 2-related factor 2 (Nrf2)/antioxidant response element (ARE) pathway is important in the cellular response to oxidative/electrophilic stress (OES) because the cellular antioxidant defense component ARE is under the transcriptional control of Nrf2.(68) Because Keap1 regulates Nrf2-mediated transcription, it serves as a therapeutic target for oxidative stress-associated disorders. Deny and colleagues developed moderately reactive dual cysteine trapping Keap1 agonists with a potentially increased target residence time.(69) The three analogues shown in Figure 18 produced greater induction of ARE when tether group rigidity was high, as evidenced from flexible butane (50) to rigid butene (51) and butyne (52) tethers. On the basis of these results, the authors concluded that optimal distance and favorable conformational arrangement of both Michael acceptors are necessary for effective interaction with the Keap1.

    Mycobacterium Protein Tyrosine Phosphatase B (mPTPB) Inhibitors 53 and 54

    Mycobacterium tuberculosis secretes an essential virulence mPTPB phosphatase into the host macrophage.(70) It has been shown that mPTPB inhibition by small molecules will increase intrinsic host signaling pathways to tackle TB infection.(71) Therefore, He and co-workers decided to develop potent and selective benzofuran salicylic acid scaffold-based mPTPB inhibitors.(72) Reduction of an unsaturated rigid alkyne spacer in 54 to an ethyl bridge led to 53 with a substantial suppression of mPTPB inhibitory potency, thus highlighting favorable contribution of a directionally rigid pendant C3-substituent of the benzofuran salicylic acid scaffold to effectively interact with the mPTPB enzyme (Figure 19).

    Calcium Sensing Receptor Antagonists 55 and 56

    Parathyroid hormone secretion is regulated by the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR) that is expressed on the surface of parathyroid cells.(73) CaSR antagonists imitate a state of hypocalcaemia, which leads to enhanced release of parathyroid hormone.(74) Consequently, Widler and colleagues developed CaSR antagonists based on the quinazolinone scaffold.(75) One optimized lead, 55, with the C6-allyloxy substituent, showed potent inhibition of CaSR. Further improvement in CaSR antagonist activity was realized by replacing the C6-allyloxy substituent in 55 with the C6-propargyloxy group as in 56 (Figure 20).

    Histone Deacetylase 8 (HDAC8) Inhibitors 57–59

    The majority of the HDAC inhibitors are pan-HDAC inhibitors. Thus, there is an urgent need for isoform-specific HDAC inhibitors to not only understand biological functions of individual HDAC isoforms but also to develop tolerable clinical candidates. Toward this goal, Ingham and colleagues described the synthesis of highly potent and selective HDAC8 inhibitors.(76) Among 70 compounds synthesized, 57 showed inhibition of HDAC8 at a subnanomolar concentration. Sequential reduction of the alkyne moiety to ethene (58) or ethyl (59) resulted in loss of HDAC8 inhibitory activity, thus substantiating favorable contribution of an alkyne linker between the 1,2,3-triazole ring and the cyclopropyl moiety (Figure 21).

    Discovery of Metabotropic Glutamate Receptor 5 (MGluR5) Antagonist 64 (Mavoglurant)

    mGluR5 subtype is involved in a number of pathologies, including anxiety and Parkinson’s disease.(77) Therefore, Vranesic and co-workers developed clinically effective mGluR5 antagonists.(19) These efforts resulted in acetylene-containing early lead compound 60, with a submicromolar potency in fluorescent imaging plate reader (FLIPR) and 2-methyl-6-(3-methoxyphenyl)ethynylpyridine (M-MPEP) displacement assays. To establish the importance of an acetylene linker between the phenyl ring and the octahydroindole ring, they synthesized cis- (61) and trans-double-bond (62) and single-bond (63) analogues, which led to noticeable loss of potency compared to 60. Having established the key role of an acetylene group, they retained an acetylene group and conducted molecular modifications at the pendant phenyl ring and the carbamate ester, leading to the discovery of 64 (AFQ056)(19) as a clinical candidate (Figure 22).

    Targeting DCN1–UBE2M Interaction by Inhibitors 65–68

    Defective in cullin neddylation 1 (DCN1) is overexpressed in squamous cell carcinomas.(78) Blocking the interaction of DCN1 and ubiquitin conjugating enzyme E2M (UBE2M) has been shown to reduce cullin3 neddylation.(79) Therefore, disrupting the interaction of DCN1 with UBE2M is considered a strategy to develop anticancer drugs. Consequently, Zhou and colleagues designed small molecules that targets a pocket on DCN1 that binds to UBE2M.(80) To determine robust binding affinities, they used two competitive binding assays such as fluorescence polarization (FP) and homogeneous time-resolved fluorescence (HTRF). Compound 65 demonstrated a low nanomolar potency in both the assays. To elucidate the importance of a propargyl substituent in 65 for potent inhibition of DCN1–UBE2M interaction, they synthesized and tested compounds 66 and 67 (featuring sequential reduction of a C≡C triple bond) with a dramatic loss of potency (Figure 23). While retaining the required propargyl group, they replaced the chlorine atom with an isosteric/isolipophilic methyl to obtain the most potent inhibitor 68. Predicted binding model of 68 within the binding pocket of DCN1 revealed favorable hydrophobic interactions of a terminal alkyne group at the sterically compact pocket surrounded by Ile83 and Ile86.

    Discovery of Dipeptidyl Peptidase-4 (DPP-4) Inhibitor 71 (Linagliptin)

    DPP-4 is a well-established target of drugs to treat type 2 diabetes. Eckhardt and co-workers began DPP-4 inhibitor development program using one of the early lead compounds 69 that feature a dimethylallyl group at N7-position of the dihydropurine scaffold.(81) Although 69 exhibited potent inhibition of DPP-4, it had unacceptably high inhibition of human ether-a-go-go (hERG) channel and high affinity for the muscarinic M1 receptor. Therefore, the dimethylallyl group was replaced with 2-butynyl group, leading to 70 with improved DPP-4 inhibition and eliminated unfavorable interaction with hERG channel and M1 receptor (Figure 24). Finally, phenacyl N1-substituent was replaced with 4-methylquinazolin-2-yl-methyl moiety to obtain linagliptin (71, BI 1356).(81) The X-ray crystal structure of 71 bound to DPP-4 concluded favorable binding of the 2-butynyl group in S1 hydrophobic pocket that not only contributed toward improved potency but also to the long residence time of the inhibitor.

    B-Raf Inhibitors 72 (Vemurafenib) and 73

    B-Raf serine/threonine kinase is a key component of mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) signaling pathway.(82) B-Raf mutations such as V600E are frequently detected in human cancers.(83) Therefore, selective inhibition of B-RafV600E mutant-driven human cancers is an attractive strategy. Although 72 (vemurafenib) is approved for the treatment of metastatic and unresectable melanoma harboring B-Raf mutations,(84) it suffers from intrinsic or acquired resistance.(85) Therefore, Li and co-workers began structural optimization of 72.(86) They replaced the carbonyl group with a conformation- and distance-favorable ethynyl linker to correctly position the hinge binding bicyclic core 1H-7-azaindazole and a back pocket binding difluorophenyl moiety to obtain 73 with superior in vitro and in vivo profile (Figure 25).

    CRTH2 Receptor Antagonists 74–76

    Chemoattractant receptor-homologous expressed in Th2 lymphocytes (CRTH2) is largely expressed by Th2 cells, eosinophils, and basophils, and thus it is involved in allergic diseases.(87) Consequently, Crosignani and co-workers decided to develop potent, selective, and orally active CRTH2 antagonists as a possible treatment of allergic and inflammatory diseases.(88) A focused screening of 8500 compound library identified 74 as a potent CRTH2 inhibitor. Replacement of the amide linker between the two aromatic rings by a rigid acetylene linker produced 75, with retention of affinity toward CRTH2 receptor. It was observed that the two aromatic rings in 75 assumed similar orientation as seen in the more active trans-amide analogue 74. However, both 74 and 75 suffer from very high serum protein binding due to their lipophilic acidic property. To address this concern, further polarity-enhancing modifications were made involving an isosteric replacement of the chloro with a fluoro and insertion of an n-propylsulfone moiety para to the fluoro to obtain orally active compound 76 with enhanced potency compared to 74 and 75 (Figure 26).

    Tumor Necrosis Factor-α (TNFα) Converting Enzyme (TACE) Inhibitors 77 and 78

    TNFα is a major proinflammatory cytokine that is implicated in the pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis.(89) A soluble form of TNFα (17 kDa) is cleaved from the membrane bound TNFα (26 kDa) by the action of metalloproteinase TACE. Therefore, the development of TACE inhibitors is an attractive approach for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. The X-ray crystal structure of TACE inhibitor 77 bound to the active site of TACE indicated the binding of the phenyl–pyridyl (biaryl) system in a shallow hydrophobic S1 pocket surrounded by residues Val314 and Leu350.(90) Although 77 showed potent inhibition of TACE, it exhibited poor activity in the presence of human whole blood. Therefore, Girijavallabhan and colleagues optimized this lead further with the assumption that internal aryl ring can be replaced with an isosteric acetylene while still projecting the terminal aryl ring in a similar orientation as observed in biaryl series.(91) These efforts culminated in the discovery of 78 with comparable TACE inhibitory activity and improved activity in a human whole blood assay (hWBA) (Figure 27).

    Histone Lysine Specific Demethylase 1 (LSD1) Inhibitors 79 and 80

    LSD1 is overexpressed in a number of human cancers, and thus LSD1 is a broadly explored anticancer drug target.(92) Therefore, Ma and co-workers synthesized LSD1-specific inhibitors to elucidate detailed biological functions of the enzyme.(93) These efforts led to the discovery of a propargyl-containing aminothiourea-pyrimidine derivative 79 with submicromolar potency against LSD1 (Figure 28). The importance of the propargyl group in 79 was assessed by replacing it with a 3,4-dichlorobenzyl moiety, leading to 80 with a substantial loss of potency. This data ascertained the importance of a propargyl group toward LSD1 inhibition. It has been shown that N5 of the flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) cofactor initiates nucleophilic attack at the propargyl group to produce covalent inactivation of LSD1.(94)

    Diacylglycerol Lipase α (DAGLα) Inhibitors 81 and 82

    A 120 kDa DAGLα contains a serine hydrolase-like catalytic triad (Ser-His-Asp) that catalyzes the hydrolysis of an ester bond of diacylglycerol (DAG) in a nucleophilic substitution 1 (SN1) specific manner to release 2-arachidonoylglycerol (2-AG).(95) 2-AG, in turn, activates the cannabinoid CB1 receptor. DAGLα is primarily expressed in the brain.(96) To understand the molecular functions of DAGLα in a temporal and dynamic fashion, Deng and co-workers designed a CNS-active chemical probe based on the most active C5-back diastereoisomer 81 with picomolar potency.(97) To visualize the target engagement, they replaced a cyclopropyl ring with an acetylene group, leading to an alkyne-containing chemical probe 82 with retention of potency and selectivity against DAGLα over α,β-hydrolase domain 6 (ABHD6) (Figure 29). The terminal acetylene present in in vivo active probe 82 will function as a ligation handle to introduce fluorescently labeled reporter groups via copper-catalyzed azide–alkyne [3 + 2] cycloaddition to assess target engagement events.

    Modulation of Drug Metabolism Pharmacokinetic (DMPK) Profile Using the Ethyne Group

    Isosteric Replacement of the Benzyl with a Propargyl to Improve Metabolic Stability

    Dragovich and co-workers reported pharmacokinetic optimization of 2-pyridone class of human rhinovirus 3C protease inhibitors.(98) For example, the 3,4-difluorobenzyl P2 moiety present in 83 was replaced with a propargyl moiety to obtain 84 with a marginal loss of potency. Interestingly, compound 84 is manifested with a number of attractive properties such as increased polarity, aqueous solubility, metabolic stability, and plasma half-life (Figure 30).

    Methylvinyl to Vinylacetylene Modification to Enhance Oral Bioavailability

    Replacement of metabolically labile methylvinyl substituent in antirhinovirus enviroxime analogue 85 by a vinylacetylene moiety led to 86, with a 3-fold improved inhibitory activity in poliovirus plaque reduction assay and increased blood levels in rhesus monkeys after oral administration (Figure 31).(99)

    Improvement of Pharmacokinetic Profile of 87 (Zileuton)

    Compound 87, a 5-lipoxygenase inhibitor, has a very short half-life as a result of fast glucuronide conjugation at N-hydroxyurea pharmacophore. Because N-hydroxyurea moiety is essential for the activity, Bouska and colleagues modified the template and linker regions of 87.(28) Replacement of the benzothiophene template with a fluorophenoxyphenyl and insertion of an ethylene linker led to 88 with a decrease in UDPGT rate and plasma clearance and increase in plasma half-life. Further improvement in UDPGT rate, plasma clearance, and plasma half-life was accomplished when ethylene linker was replaced with an acetylene moiety as in 89. Isosteric replacement of the 4-fluorophenoxyphenyl moiety in 89 with a 4-fluorobenzylthiophene moiety led to 90 with desirable UDPGT rate, plasma clearance, and plasma half-life (Figure 32).

    Increased Metabolic Stability of Steroidal Drugs 91–96

    Among several alkyne-containing steroidal drugs, a representative set of them (91–96) are presented in Figure 33. Because the C17β-OH group in steroidal drugs was shown to undergo 17β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase-mediated oxidation to the much less active C17-keto metabolite,(100,101) C17α-ethynyl or -propargyl group was introduced to prevent this oxidation and thus render them orally active. In addition, the propargyl alcohol moiety in these steroids ensure reduced androgenic activity.

    CYP1B1 Selective Inhibitors 97 and 98

    CYP1B1 is responsible for metabolic inactivation of anticancer drugs such as docetaxel, paclitaxel, and cisplatin.(102) Additionally, it is involved in the bioactivation of a wide range of procarcinogens. Further overexpression of CYP1B1 is observed in several types of human cancers.(103) Therefore, CYP1B1 serves as a target to achieve multiple therapeutic goals. Dutour and colleagues reported greater selectivity of estrogens toward CYP1B1 over CYP1A1 when the C17α-ethynyl group was inserted as evidenced from compounds 97 and 98 (Figure 34).(104) An additional reason for installation of the C17α-ethynyl group was to protect the C17β-hydroxy group from undergoing metabolic oxidation.(100,101)

    Disrupters of the Glucokinase–Glucokinase Regulatory Protein (GK-GKRP) Interaction

    Glucokinase activators are antidiabetic agents; however, they suffer from hypoglycemia.(105) Therefore, St. Jean and colleagues synthesized novel compounds with a potential to disrupt GK–GKRP interaction with a concomitant mitigation of the hypoglycemia.(106) Although initial lead compound 99 was potent in biochemical assays, it lacked metabolic stability (Figure 35). The lack of metabolic stability was attributed to the presence of a methyl-substituted morpholine ring. Further, it was observed that the thiophene binding site contained a pair of hydrogen bond acceptor groups. Therefore, the thiophene ring was replaced with hydrogen bond donating moiety such as aminopyridine and the methyl substituted morpholinylmethyl moiety was replaced with the hydrogen to obtain 100 with a drastic improvement in metabolic stability. Addition of a propargyl substituent onto the piperazine ring led to the discovery of 101 (AMG-3969) with a >20-fold increased potency and desirable metabolic stability.(106)

    Ghrelin Inverse Agonists 102–105

    Ghrelin is a 28-amino acid long “hunger hormone”, which upon octanoylation becomes effective endogenous agonist for the growth hormone secretagogue receptor (GHSR). Activation of GHSR leads to increased food intake and thus plays a key role in obesity-related metabolic diseases.(107) Therefore, the development of GHSR inverse agonist would reduce food intake. Consequently, Daina and colleagues began structure-based design and development of GHSR inverse agonists.(108) The para-cyclopropyl analogue 102 gave a moderate potency, whereas para-ethynyl analogue 103 showed a substantial improvement in potency. However, 103 suffered from poor metabolic stability. To increase metabolic stability, ethynyl and cyclopropyl substituents were combined, leading to a para-cyclopropylethynyl analogue 104 with good potency and increased metabolic stability. Chiral separation of 104 revealed the (R)-isomer to be the more potent diastereomer (105) (Figure 36).

    Enhanced Target Selectivity with an Acetylene

    The development of inhibitors with a defined selectivity profile has been a priority for drug discovery scientists to limit off-target effects. Toward this objective, the acetylene group has contributed to the development of isoform-selective ligands as supported by following examples.

    Insertion of an Acetylene Group in DPP-4 Inhibitor Enhanced Target Selectivity

    Madar and colleagues developed DPP-4 specific inhibitors over closely related isoforms DPP-8 and DPP-9.(109) They installed an acetylene group at the C5-position of 2-cyanopyrrolidine moiety in 106 to obtain 107 with a considerable improvement in DPP-4 selectivity over DPP-8 and DPP-9 compared to 106. While retaining the cyano and acetylene substituted pyrrolidine ring, they replaced the cyclohexyloxy linker by C4-methylpiperidine and cyanopyridine ring by the isonicotinic acid to obtain compound 108 (ABT-279),(109) with further improvement in potency and selectivity (Figure 37).

    Propargyl Derivative (110) of Retigabine (109) as Potent KCNQ4 and KCNQ5 Channel Agonist

    KCNQ is a subfamily of voltage-gated potassium ion channels comprising five members (KCNQ1–5). Among these subtypes, KCNQ4 and KCNQ5 channels are involved in visceral smooth muscle-related diseases such as overactive bladder syndrome and irritable bowel syndrome.(110) Therefore, Wang and colleagues synthesized KCNQ4 and KCNQ5 channel selective agonists.(111) Insertion of the N1-propargyl and N3-Boc groups in nonselective 109 (retigabine) led to 110, with improved KCNQ4/5 subtype specificity (Figure 38).

    Structural Role of an Acetylene Group

    The alkyne group has been widely used as a structural motif due to its narrow, rod-like configuration to traverse sterically restricted channels within the target protein. Being electron-rich, it was further used to establish potency enhancing π–π interactions with the active site aromatic residues. Moreover, it serves as an effective sterically less demanding linker to create symmetric dimeric compounds directed at the two adjacent binding sites on the target macromolecule. Additionally, it can be used as a connecting bridge to sterically restrict the bioactive conformation and enhancing target selectivity.

    Phosphinic Pseudotripeptide Inhibitors (111 and 112) of Aminopeptidases

    The three major aminopeptidases, including endoplasmic reticulum aminopeptidase 1 (ERAP1), ERAP2, and insulin-regulated aminopeptidase (IRAP), are involved in pruning antigenic peptides.(112−114) Therefore, these enzymes serves as drug targets for the regulation of immune responses.(115) Replacement of the P1′ Ile side chain in 111 with a propargyl group led to 112 with increased inhibition of three aminopeptidases (Figure 39).(116) Kokkala and co-workers speculated that the potency increase was a result of favorable interactions between the electron-rich propargyl group and the catalytic Zn2+ atom. However, an X-ray crystal structure was unavailable to confirm this hypothesis.(116) Recently, Giastas and colleagues(117) determined a high-resolution (1.60 Å) structure of ERAP1 bound to 112 (DG046). The X-ray structure showed localization of a propargyl group into the S1′ pocket of the ERAP1 active site, where it forms potency enhancing π–π interactions with the aromatic cloud of the zinc2+-coordinating His353.

    Discovery of Bcr-Abl Kinase Inhibitor 115

    Bcr-Abl kinase play a key role in chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), and thus it serves as oncology drug target.(118) Clinical use of compound 113 (imatinib) in CML patients is associated with drug resistance as a result of mutation at the gatekeeper residue (Thr315Ile).(119) Bulky side chain of Ile315 produces a steric clash with 113 and a concomitant >400-fold loss of binding affinity (Figure 40).(119,120) Compound 114 (ponatinib) was designed to contain an alkyne linker between the adenine-binding moiety and allosteric pocket-binding moiety to avoid steric clash with the bulky side chain of Ile315 as evidenced from potent inhibition of both wild-type and mutant Bcr-Abl kinase.(121) Although 114 was useful for targeting both wild-type and resistant Bcr-Abl kinases, it suffered from side effects such as blood clots and narrowing of blood vessels. Therefore, Liu and co-workers developed new generation Bcr-Abl kinase inhibitors wherein a novel adenine-binding moiety and allosteric pocket-binding moiety was linked via an alkyne group.(120) These efforts culminated in compound 115 with a balanced subnanomolar inhibition of wild-type as well as Thr315Ile mutant Bcr-Abl kinase.

    Stem Cell Factor Receptor KIT Inhibitor 116

    The tyrosine kinase mast/stem cell growth factor receptor KIT is a validated target for the development of cancer therapeutics to treat gastrointestinal stromal tumors and CML. However, this strategy failed due to acquired resistance mutations in the catalytic domain of KIT. Consequently, Kaitsiotou and colleagues developed a novel KIT inhibitor 116 that addresses this problem.(122) To do so, they connected hinge binding element to the back pocket moiety via an acetylene linker which allowed maximum affinity toward the gatekeeper Thr670Ile mutation (Figure 41).

    Type II Inhibitor (117) of Maternal Embryonic Leucine Zipper Kinase (MELK)

    MELK is a target for cancer therapeutics development.(123) Johnson and co-workers designed and synthesized compound 117 as a type II inhibitor of MELK (Figure 42).(124) The propargyloxy linker having a low steric demand traverses a narrow connecting tunnel lined by gatekeeper residue Leu86 and the DFG motif residue Phe151, allowing the aminoisoquinoline moiety to effectively interact with the hinge residues.

    Hsp90 Inhibitors 118 and 119

    Heat shock protein 90 (Hsp90) is a well-established target for anticancer drug development.(125) Hsp90 inhibitors are primarily indicated for HER-2 positive breast cancers. Shi and colleagues began optimization of 118,(126) which required higher doses (100 mg twice daily) in the phase 2 clinical study.(127) The X-ray crystal structure of 118 with Hsp90 showed that the N7 lone pair of 118 were facing the solvent-exposed region. Thus, the N7 was considered to be the desired vector for installation of various substituents. To achieve this goal, the N7 needed to be replaced with a carbon atom and subsequent addition of substituents such as 2-methylpent-4-yn-2-ol, which led to the more potent analogue 119 (EC144) (Figure 43).(127) Further 119 demonstrated improved efficacy in mice compared to 118. The X-ray cocrystal structure of 119-Hsp90 revealed hydrophobic interaction between the alkyne moiety and the side chain of Met98 and Leu107.

    Pseudomonas aeruginosa Deacetylase LpxC Inhibitor 120

    The zinc metallo enzyme LpxC (UDP-3-O(-acyl)-N-acetylglucosamine deacetylase) is necessary for the growth of several Gram-negative bacteria, including P. aeruginosa.(128) Compound 120, a potent inhibitor of LpxC, showed substantial antipseudomonal activity in both in vitro and in vivo studies (Figure 44).(129) The X-ray crystal structure of P. aeruginosa LpxC bound to 120 confirmed favorable binding of the butynyl ether tail moiety into a hydrophobic tunnel by engaging with Ile197.

    Pseudomonas aeruginosa Deacetylase LpxC Inhibitors 121−123

    Lee and colleagues described development of a novel LpxC inhibitor 121 with picomolar Kd value against P. aeruginosa.(130) Importance of an alkyne moiety in 121 and 123 is evidenced from the less potent analogue 122 that lacks an alkyne motif (Figure 45). The X-ray cocrystal structure of 121-P. aeruginosa LpxC enzyme showed that the cyclopropylalkyne moiety forms hydrophobic interactions with the nonpolar residues of the lipophilic tunnel such that the cyclopropyl moiety extends into the solvent-exposed region of P. aeruginosa LpxC enzyme.

    The Design of Dimeric Smac Mimetics Through a 1,3-Bisacetylene Spacer

    Second mitochondrial activator of caspases (Smac) is the endogenous inhibitor of a family of inhibitor of apoptosis proteins (IAPs). Because Smac protein is known to interact with the IAPs as a dimer,(131) Hennessy and co-workers decided to dimerize two monomeric Smac mimetic tetrapeptide components through a sterically less demanding linear 1,3-bisacetylene spacer to obtain a clinical candidate 124 (AZD5582) (Figure 46).(132) Compound 124 simultaneously binds to both baculovirus IAP repeat (BIR2 and BIR3) domains of X chromosome-linked inhibitor of apoptosis (XIAP) and thus disrupt the interactions between XIAP and caspases, which leads to apoptosis.

    Tazarotene (126)

    Compound 126 belong to a conformationally constrained nonisomerizable topical retinoids. All-trans-retinoic acid (125/tretinoin) is nonselective toward retinoid receptors due to its relatively flexible conformation. Consequently, tazarotene (126) structure featuring the thiocroman and pyridine rings and a connecting acetylene bridge offer restricted conformation and thus demonstrate receptor selectivity toward RARβ and RARγ (Figure 47).(133,134)

    Ethyne as a Latent Electrophile for Irreversible Inhibitor Design

    The development of covalent inhibitors with high selectivity toward a desired target has increasingly becoming popular in the clinic due to (1) enhanced biochemical efficiency, (2) beneficial PK profile, (3) longer duration of action because recovery of target protein activity is only possible through de novo synthesis, which allows for low treatment doses, and (4) efficient approach in situations where a complete loss of target function is desired.(135) However, the use of highly reactive electrophilic warheads can potentially lead to indiscriminate covalent modification of off-target proteins and concurrent idiosyncratic toxicity. Therefore, the use of less reactive electrophilic warhead groups such as alkyne functionality is of particular interest as evident from the following selected examples.

    Covalent Inhibitors of Bruton Tyrosine Kinase (127–129)

    Acalabrutinib (127),(136) tirabrutinib (128),(137) and branebrutinib (129)(138) featuring butynamide warhead group are small-molecule irreversible inhibitors of anticancer target, bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK). As an example, the reactive butynamide warhead in 127 covalently reacts with the thiol of Cys481 at the rim of the BTK active site (Figure 48).(136) Compared to the more reactive warheads known to target Cys residues of various kinases, butynamides appear to exhibit reduced reactivity and as a result limit inhibition of off-target kinases having analogous cysteine residues.

    Covalent Nek2 Inhibitor 130

    Overexpression of Nek2 has been linked with a number of cancers, including primary breast tumors(139) and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.(140) Thus, Nek2 inhibitors are potentially useful as anticancer agents. Henise and co-workers developed the first cell-active irreversible propynamide-based Nek2 inhibitor 130 (Figure 49).(141) Compound 130 has been shown to label Cys22 within the active site of Nek2 as evidenced from the mass spectrometry analysis. Further, it failed to label C22V mutant Nek2, which suggest its site-specific labeling ability.

    Irreversible p97 Inhibitor 131

    Adenosine triphosphatase p97 has been actively pursued as an anticancer target.(142,143) Ding and co-workers(144) developed butynamide warhead-containing compound 131 as a Cys522 targeted irreversible inhibitor of p97 (Figure 50). Proposed binding models and site-directed mutagenesis experiments validated labeling of Cys522 by compound 131.

    EGFR Cys797 Targeted Inhibitor 132

    Wood and colleagues designed a thienopyrimidine derivative 132 featuring an ethynyl pyrrolidine warhead as a Cys797 targeted covalent inhibitor of anticancer target EGFR.(145) The covalent complex shown in Figure 51 was deduced based on the mass spectrometry analysis.

    N-Propargyl Amides as Covalent Inhibitors of Cysteinyl Proteases

    Arkona and co-workers investigated the suitability of N-propargylamides as active site cysteine targeted irreversible inhibitors of cysteinyl proteases.(146) For example, the C-terminal propargylamide derivative of ubiquitin irreversibly inhibited deubiquitinating enzyme (DUB) isopeptidase in a stoichiometric manner (Figure 52A and 52B). Addition of a terminal methyl group or a gem-dimethyl moiety on a propargyl unit prevented the thiol addition reaction as shown in Figure 52C.(147) This underscores the context-dependent change in the reactivity of an alkyne group toward the active site cysteine residue.

    Transforming Reversible Cathepsin K (CatK) Inhibitor 133 to Latent Electrophile-Containing Irreversible Inhibitor 134

    Cysteinyl protease CatK overexpressed in osteoclasts is involved in bone degradation.(148) Therefore, small-molecule inhibitors of CatK are useful for the treatment of osteoporosis. To offset idiosyncratic toxicity associated with highly reactive electrophilic groups in irreversible inhibitors, Mons and co-workers developed CatK inhibitors, containing less reactive warheads such as N-propargylamide.(149) Compound 133 (odanacatib) is a highly selective reversible covalent inhibitor of CatK due to the presence of a cysteine reactive nitrile group. These investigators conveniently replaced the nitrile group in 133 with an alkyne isostere, however, they noticed decreased aqueous solubility. This problem was resolved by removing hydrophobic spirocyclopropyl moiety, leading to 134 that exhibited less electrophilic N-propargyl amide warhead compared to widely known acrylamide warheads. Compound 134 was able to form irreversible thioether bond by in situ thiol-alkyne addition. The X-ray crystal structure studies confirmed the formation of a covalent thiol adduct at Cys25 (Figure 53).

    Dihydropyrimidine Dehydrogenase (DHPDHase) Inactivating Compound 135

    DHPDHase catalyzes reversible reduction of pyrimidines to 5,6-dihydropyrimidines as the first step to generate β-amino acids. Therefore, DHPDHase has been considered as a key target for modulation of 5-fluorouracil chemotherapy. Porter and colleagues reported mechanism-based inactivation of DHPDHase by a novel 5-ethynyluracil analogue (135) (Figure 54).(150) Among various C5-substituents such as ethynyl (kinact,app/min = 5.64), diazo (kinact,app/min = 1.68), cyano (kinact,app/min = 0.78), bromovinyl (kinact,app/min = 0.60), propynyl (kinact,app/min = 0.46), bromo (kinact,app/min = 0.42), and trifluoromethyl (kinact,app/min = 0.23), ethynyl substituent produced the fastest rate of inactivation of DHPDHase. By comparing the rate of inactivation by ethyne versus propyne analogues, one would conclude that C≡C triple bond demonstrate context-dependent reactivity toward endogenous nucleophiles.

    LSD1 Inhibitor 136

    The lysine specific demethylase 1 (LSD1) play a key role in androgen dependent gene expression and has been shown to become overexpressed in prostate cancers.(151) Therefore, LSD1 inhibitors are useful for the treatment of hormone-dependent cancers. Consequently, Schmitt and co-workers began development of covalent LSD1 inhibitors using MAO inhibitory propargylamine as an initial structural core.(152) Compound 136 showed dual inhibition of LSD1 and MAO-B enzymes (Figure 55). Computational docking of 136 within the active site of LSD1 indicated the proximity of N-propargylamine group to the reactive N5 of the FAD cofactor. Preincubation of 136 with LSD1 and subsequent dilution resulted in loss of enzyme activity, thus confirming the irreversible mechanism of inhibition.

    Covalent Inhibitors (137–139) of Monoamine Oxidase B (MAO-B)

    MAO-B inhibitors are useful in the treatment of depression and Parkinson’s disease. Clinically useful propargyl-containing MAO-B inhibitors such as 137 (selegiline), 138 (rasagiline), and 139 (pargyline) irreversibly inhibits MAO-B by forming adduct between its terminal acetylene CH and the N5 of FAD cofactor (Figure 56).(153) This covalent binding mechanism was further supported by X-ray crystal structure studies.(154)

    Propargylamine-Derived Multitarget-Directed Ligands (MTDLs) in the Treatment of Neurodegenerative Diseases

    Single-target-directed drugs exert less than desirable therapeutic effect in patients with Alzheimer’s disease (AD).(155) This is not surprising because progress and development of AD involves an interplay of multiple biochemical targets, including acetylcholinesterase (AChE),(156) monoamine oxidase (MAO),(157) biometal ions (iron, copper and zinc),(158) oxidative stress,(159) amyloid β aggregation and plaque formation,(160) apoptosis,(161) inflammatory cytokines,(162) and adenosine receptors.(163) Consequently, the design strategy for MTDLs has gained increasing acceptance for the discovery of novel therapies to treat multifactorial AD. The MTDLs design strategy involves molecular hybridization of different pharmacophoric moieties of different drugs in the same structure with the assumption that individual pharmacophore will engage intended target site. The propargylamine-containing MAO inhibitors produce neuroprotective effect through biochemical mechanisms, such as antioxidant,(164) antiapoptotic activity, anti-inflammatory, and promoting nonamyloidogenic pathway,(165) besides their potential to increase amine neurotransmission. Therefore, all of the MTDLs discovered so far possess one common MAO-inhibitory pharmacophore, i.e., propargylamine moiety (Figure 57).
    Compound 140 is synthesized and evaluated as a potent and selective inhibitor of MAO-B that also exhibited neuroprotective effect in animal models.(166) Compound 141 was designed as a potent dual MAO and AChE inhibitor by combining the MAO inhibitory and neuroprotective activities of 140 and AChE inhibitory pharmacophore N-benzylpiperidine.(167) Compound 142 (ladostigil), failed in phase 2b clinical trials, was developed as a dual inhibitor by combining MAO inhibitory propargylamine moiety and cholinesterase inhibitory carbamate moiety.(168) Apart from MAO and cholinesterase inhibitory properties, 142 showed antiapoptotic and neuroprotective activity that is unrelated to its MAO inhibitory activity.(169) Compound 142 contain a chiral center, and its activity resides in the (R)-enantiomer. Further, its carbamate group is known to undergo hydrolytic degradation to a metabolite that possess neuroprotective activity but lack cholinesterase inhibitory activity. To circumvent these problems, Denya and colleagues(170) designed a structurally similar analogue 143 that replaces the indane ring with the indole ring to eliminate chiral center and the carbamate group with a stable diethylurea group. Compound 143 demonstrated superior dual inhibitory activity toward cholinesterase and MAO enzymes compared to 142. Cholinesterase inhibitory tacrine ring amino substituent was hybridized with MAO inhibitory propargylamine-containing motif to obtain dual inhibitor 144. Compound 144 demonstrated nanomolar potency against cholinesterase and MAO.(171) Wang and colleagues(172) synthesized and evaluated a novel class of multifunctional anti-AD agents by combining N-benzylpiperidine, N-propargylamine, and 8-hydroxyquinoline structural features that target cholinesterase, MAO, and neuroprotective biometal chelation, respectively. These efforts led to the identification of compound 145, with potent inhibition of cholinesterase and MAO and efficient biometal ion chelation. Further continuation of this design strategy led to compound 146 with improved cholinesterase inhibitory potency and selectivity toward MAO-A over MAO-B and retention of biometal chelation property.(173) Bautista-Aguilera and co-workers(174) synthesized a dual inhibitor 147 by molecular hybridization of AChE and MAO inhibitory pharmacophores. Because adenosine receptor antagonism contribute to neuroprotective action, Koch and colleagues(175) synthesized a bifunctional compound 148 that has adenosine receptor targeting tetrahydropyrimidopurinedione pharmacophore and MAO-targeting N-propargyl moiety (Figure 57).

    Acetylene-Containing Natural Products

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    More than 1000 alkyne-containing natural products or natural product derived compounds have been reported.(176) Herein, a representative set of natural products or their semisynthetic counterparts are described to reflect upon alkyne presence in nature.

    Discovery of Ironomycin (150)

    Salinomycin (149) is a monocarboxylic acid-containing polyether with cell membrane ionophore activity.(177) Ironomycin (150), a semisynthetic analogue, is derived from 149 by substituting a hydroxyl group with a propargylamine moiety (Figure 58). This molecular modification led to an order of magnitude higher potency than 149 for killing breast cancer stem cells in vitro and in vivo.(178) The ability of compound 150 to kill cancer stem cells is derived from the accumulation and sequestration of iron in lysosomes and from the subsequent production of reactive oxygen species and lysosomal membrane permeabilization.(178)
    Hitora and colleagues reported six cytotoxic durynes isolated from the marine sponge Petrosia sp.(179) The most potent cytotoxic homologue duryne E (151) is shown Figure 59. Sanchez and co-workers isolated the cyanobacterial natural product almiramide B (152) with antiparasitic activity against Leishmania donovani (Figure 59).(180) Kurahyne (153), an acetylene-containing lipopeptide isolated from the cyanobacteria has shown growth inhibitory activity toward human cancer cells and an ability to induce apoptosis in HeLa cells (Figure 59).(181) Viridamide A (154), isolated from the marine cyanobacterium Oscillatoria nigro-viridis, has shown antileishmanial and antitrypanosomal activity in low micromolar concentrations (Figure 59).(182) Companeramide A (155), isolated from a Panamanian marine cyanobacterium, has demonstrated inhibitory activity against Plasmodium falciparum Dd2 strain in nanomolar range (Figure 59).(183)
    Chai and co-workers have recently reviewed a number of alkyne-containing peptides of natural origin.(184)

    Enediyne-Based Natural Products

    The enediyne unit is a structural element of several clinically useful natural products as described below. The potent anticancer effect of these natural products is derived from their highly reactive enediyne unit, which either cleaves or cross-links genomic DNA by a novel molecular mechanism.

    Calicheamicin (156)

    Compound 156 is a group of enediyne-containing antibiotics derived from microbial cultures. The enediyne chromophore is an essential component of a strained 10-membered ring that also present a methyl trisulfide moiety.(185,186) This class of naturally occurring compounds has been extensively investigated as anticancer agents. Compound 156 contains three components: (1) a polysaccharide unit that facilitates the enediyne docking into the minor groove of DNA, (2) a trigger devise containing a methyl trisulfide group next to the conjugated cyclohexenone, and (3) a DNA targeting enediyne reactive antitumor warhead (Figure 60). GSH initiates nucleophilic attack on the trisulfide moiety to produce an intramolecular Michael addition intermediate, which, in turn, leads to contraction of the enediyne ring system and subsequent Bergman cyclization(187) of the enediyne component. A reactive para-didehydrobenzene diradical is generated and subsequently positioned to abstract two proximal hydrogens from the deoxyribose sugars on each strand of DNA and thus cause the cleavage of the double-stranded DNA and cell death while forming a stable arene byproduct (Figure 60).(188)

    Dynemicin A (157)

    Compound 157 is a member of enediyne warhead-containing antitumor antibiotics. It is comprised of a highly strained 10-membered carbocycle fused to a highly oxidized planar anthraquinone chromophore. It was originally obtained from the cultures of Micromonospora chersina.(189) Opening of the reactive epoxide group of the anthraquinone chromophore by bioreductive GSH or NADPH cofactors(190) serves as a device that triggers Bergman cycloaromatization.(187) The enediyne bridge has been shown to position toward the minor groove of the double-stranded DNA. Therefore, 157 is an example of a naturally occurring prodrug equipped with a triggering device that undergoes activation under physiological conditions. Dynemicin A frequently cut the 3′-ends of purine (adenine and guanine), which is markedly different from the cutting sites of calicheamicin. Initially, the anthraquinone ring intercalates between the adjacent bases of a DNA helix and, subsequently, phenyl diradical generated from the enediyne warhead attacks the DNA strands and triggers their cleavage. Compound 157 appears to cleave DNA strands via both alkylation and hydrogen atom abstraction (Figure 61).

    Inotuzumab Ozogamicin (158)

    It is a CD22-targeted antibody–drug conjugate (ADC) that includes three elements: (1) inotuzumab, a human CD22-specific IgG4 κ antibody, (2) N-acetyl-γ-calicheamicin that is responsible for initiating double-stranded DNA breaks similar to that described for calicheamicin, and (3) an acid-cleavable linker, which itself is a condensation product of 4-(4′-acetylphenoxy)-butanoic acid and 3-methyl-3-mercaptobutane hydrazide, facilitates covalent attachment of the N-acetyl-γ-calicheamicin to inotuzumab (Figure 62).(191) It is approved for the treatment of CD22-positive relapsed or refractory B-cell precursor acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

    Gemtuzumab Ozogamicin (159)

    It is an ADC comprised of CD33-directed monoclonal antibody that is covalently linked to a highly cytotoxic DNA strand breaking N-acetyl-γ-calicheamicin (Figure 62). The molecular mechanism of activation of this ADC is akin to that of calicheamicin. It contains an average of 2–3 moles of calicheamicin derivatives per mole of gemtuzumab.(191) It is approved for the treatment of CD33-positive acute myeloid leukemia.

    The Downsides of the Ethynyl Group in Medicinal Chemistry

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The liver plays a key role in the metabolism and clearance of drugs through conversion to hydrophilic metabolites that are easier to excrete. This role is enabled by an abundance of drug metabolizing enzymes with which the liver is equipped and among which the cytochrome P450 (CYP450) plays a key role. It is recognized that CYP450-catalyzed reactions oftentimes produce metabolites that are more reactive than the original drug. Drug-induced liver injury results in ∼2700 deaths each year in the U.S. alone.(192) A representative group of acetylene-containing FDA approved drugs are presented here to demonstrate the mechanism-based inactivation of CYP450 enzymes (Figure 63). A terminal acetylene group can alkylate the prosthetic heme chromophore or an active site nucleophilic amino acid residues of CYP450 to cause irreversible inhibition of this metabolizing system (Figure 63). Such an effect can occur through two potential pathways: (1) the oxidation of an internal acetylenic carbon that leads to the degradation of heme and (2) the oxidation of the terminal acetylenic carbon that covalently attaches to the nucleophilic residue at the active site while sparing heme (Figure 63). The acetylene-containing steroidal drugs, 17α-ethynylestradiol (93),(22) norethindrone (160), and danazole (91)(23) inactivated hepatic CYP450 enzymes by a mechanism-based alkylation of heme pyrrole nitrogen. Time-dependent inhibition of CYP450 enzymes can produce pharmacokinetic changes in simultaneously administered drugs, thus leading to a potential risk of drug–drug interactions. Activation of an acetylene group in selegiline (137) was shown to selectively inactivate CYP2B1 with a Ki of 1 μM and kinact of 0.23/min.(24) Mifepristone (96), a methyl substituted internal alkyne, potently and selectively inactivated CYP3A4 with Ki and kinact values of 4.7 μM and 0.089/min.(25)
    Many factors were shown to influence the potency, selectivity, and heme versus protein inactivation of CYP450 enzymes, and these include size and shape of the molecule, anchoring of an acetylene group, the length of an alkyne-containing side chain, and/or the presence of a terminal hydrogen or a methyl group.(26) Mechanism-based inactivation of CYP450 is the most common toxicity associated with the alkyne-containing drugs. Consequently, preclinical evaluation of metabolic routes across major CYP450 isoforms and screening for reactive metabolites becomes a requirement for chemists developing alkyne-bearing compounds for eventual use as drugs.

    Glutathione (GSH) Conjugates of Positive Allosteric Modulators (PAMs) of Metabotropic Glutamate Receptor Subtype 5 (mGluR5)

    Several mGluR5 PAMs that contain an acetylene group are susceptible toward the formation of GSH conjugates. However, it was observed that the presence of a substituent near an acetylene group controls their reactivity toward thiols.(27) An acetylene group adjacent to an electron-withdrawing N-containing heteroaromatic ring as in 161 was substantially conjugated with GSH because of its increased electrophilic character. In contrast, the cyclohexyl substituted acetylene derivative 162 did not undergo any GSH conjugation due to the diminished electrophilicity of its acetylene group. These observations highlight the importance of the electronic property of an acetylene group toward its reactivity with the thiols (Figure 64).

    HIV-1 Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitor 163 (Efavirenz)

    Compound 163 contains an acetylene group as a key pharmacophore element. After hydroxylation on the carbon next to the triple bond, 163 was shown in rats to undergo reaction with GSH to form conjugate at an internal acetylene group (Figure 65).(193) The GSH conjugate has been reported to produce nephrotoxicity in rats.(194)

    Time-Dependent Inactivation of CYP3A4 by 4 (Erlotinib)

    Compound 4, featuring a terminal alkyne, undergoes CYP3A4-mediated metabolism to produce two reactive metabolites (oxirene and ketene) that cause time-dependent inhibition of CYP3A4.(195,196) These reactive metabolites eventually give rise to the stable acetic acid metabolite (Figure 66).

    Acetylene as a Probe in Chemical Biology Research

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Determination of macromolecular level mechanism of a ligand molecule, which involves identification of target binding partners and off-target binding events, has become a critical area of research in chemical biology. Insertion of a molecular handle such as alkyne or azide allows for detection of target binding proteins in a cellular proteome via fluorescence read out or affinity purification and subsequent mass spectrometric analysis. Consequently, copper-(I)-catalyzed 1,2,3-triazole ring formation plays a key role in numerous chemical biology studies, including activity-based protein profiling (ABPP), labeling of DNA, tagging living organisms, in vivo imaging, and labeling of live cells. Copper-(I)-catalyzed azide–alkyne [3 + 2] cycloaddition (CuAAC) reaction has also played a key role in generation of new chemical libraries. CuAAC reaction with polymers contributed to the field of drug delivery. Further, the CuAAC reaction has allowed generation of cyclic peptides and the development of antibody-based therapeutics.

    Activity-Based Protein Profiling (ABPP)

    An elegant use of CuAAC chemistry between an acetylene handle and electrophilic reactive groups allows the identification of target proteins. ABPP is a well established chemocentric method comprising three components: (1) an electrophilic group to react covalently with nucleophiles at the active site, (2) a binding group that directs the chemical probe toward a desired protein target, and (3) a pendant secondary handle such as terminal acetylene group to monitor the expression levels and function in complex protein mixtures via click chemistry (Figure 67).

    Alkyne-Containing Probes Track Vancomycin-Induced Cell Wall Changes

    Vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) is a significant public health burden. The antimicrobial mechanism of action of vancomycin involves inhibition of peptidoglycan (PG) biosynthesis. PG contains monomeric units of disaccharides that are capped with pentapeptide chains. The pentapeptide features a terminal d-Ala-d-Ala dipeptide sequence. VRE bacterial cells develop resistance to vancomycin by synthesizing alternate d-Ala-d-lactate capped PG precursors.(197,198) As a result, VRE bacterial cells can grow and proliferate under the pressure of vancomycin. To understand the PG structural plasticity associated with VRE cells, Pidgeon and colleagues designed and investigated the chemical probe 164, an alkyne-containing analogue of the VRE-linked VanB ligase substrate d-lactate.(199) This probe feature an alkyne handle suitable for CuAAC click chemistry. It was anticipated that the VanB ligases will use this modified substrate to produce the d-Ala-d-laclick PG anchor, which was subsequently subjected to CuAAC click chemistry with an azido-fluorophore such as 6-carboxyfluorescein azide (6-FAM-azide). The development of vancomycin resistance was indicated by observing increases in the fluorescence levels (Figure 68).
    Pidgeon and colleagues hypothesized that a synthetic mimic of d-Ala-d-Ala terminal dipeptide unit such as probe 165 as the d,d-dipeptidase (VanX) substrate would allow for in vivo interrogation of VanX activity in VRE bacterial cells.(200) Consequently, a clickable dipeptide 165 featuring an alkyne group for conducting click chemistry was designed using 6-FAM-azide (Figure 68). A decrease in the fluorescence of this chemical probe was associated with the development of drug resistance.

    Alkyne-Azido-Containing Chemical Probe for Labeling Target Proteins Involved in Ebola Virus Infection

    Compound 166 is a potent inhibitor of Ebola virus infection (IC50 = 20 nM). It features an aromatic azide for UV-mediated photolabeling of the target proteins and a terminal acetylene handle for azide–alkyne [3 + 2] cycloaddition reaction with Alexa-fluor 488-azide. Incubation of the Niemann–Pick C1 (NPC1) protein expressing CHO cells with 166 and subsequent exposure to UV light led to 166 cross-linked proteins (Figure 69). The cross-linked product was then subjected to click chemistry using Alexa-fluor 488-azide and analyzed by immunoblot probed with Alexa-fluor 488 antibody. This analysis led to the identification of NPC1 as the host molecular target for compound 166.(201)

    Artemisinin-Derived Alkyne Chemical Probe

    Reactive endoperoxide-containing artemisinins (ART, 167) are a class of important antimalarial agents whose mechanism of action remains poorly understood. To attain this goal, Ismail and co-workers developed the ART activity-based chemical probe 168 for in situ identification of malarial parasite protein drug targets (Figure 70).(202) Chemical probe 168 demonstrated comparable in vitro potency and ability to alkylate target proteins of Plasmodium falciparum 3D7 parasites to that observed for the parent ART. Target proteins covalently tagged with ART probe were isolated via click chemistry with a trifunctional rhodamine-biotin azide in the form of conjugated 1,2,3-triazoles. These functionalized target proteins were subjected to streptavidin affinity purification, trypsin digestion on beads, and LC-MS/MS analysis, which revealed alkylated target proteins belonging to the antioxidant defense, hemoglobin degradation, glycolytic, and protein synthesis pathways. All of these pathways are critical for the survival of malarial parasites.

    SAHA (169)-Derived Activity-Based Photo-Cross-linking Chemical Probe for Histone Deacetylases

    The FDA approved reversible HDAC inhibitor 169 (SAHA/vorinostat) was converted to the activity-based probe 170 by inserting a photoactivatable benzophenone moiety and an acetylene handle (Figure 71).(203,204)

    Clickable Transglutaminase 2 (TG2) Inhibitor (171)

    Dafik and colleagues developed 3-bromodihydroisoxazole (DHI)-based chemical probes such as 171 for the labeling and subsequent visualization of the catalytically active transglutaminase 2 (Figure 72).(205) The DHI moiety functions as a warhead to covalently inhibit TG2 via thioether bond formation. A terminal aromatic acetylene handle participates in the azide–alkyne [3 + 2] cycloaddition reaction with a biotin-conjugated azide to produce triazole as a reporter group. These compounds were selective for TG2 proteins and allowed visualization of the location of active TG2 in cells using the streptavidin-conjugated form of biotin.(205)

    Alkyne-Containing Probes for a Covalent Labeling of CYP450s in an Activity-Dependent Manner

    Wright and co-workers synthesized and functionally characterized a series of alkyne-containing probes to profile CYP450s in native biological systems.(206) These probe molecules (172) represent three structural features: (1) a reactive group that covalently binds to the enzyme active site, (2) a binding group that specifically direct the probe to a desired enzyme family, and (3) a latent clickable alkyne handle to attach a reporter group for visualizing labeling events. The labeling events were detected by linking the fluorescent rhodamine-azide reporter via azide–alkyne click chemistry onto the probe–CYP450 covalent adducts (Figure 73).

    Natural Product Hypothemycin (173) Derivatized to an Alkyne for the Identification of Therapeutic Target

    Hypothemycin (173), a polyketide natural product, covalently inhibits various human kinases.(207) Compound 174, a semisynthetic derivative of hypothemycin containing a terminal alkyne handle, was developed for use as a chemical probe. Because 173 showed potent trypanocidal activity, a propargyl-containing affinity probe 174 with activity equipotent to 173 was synthesized for click conjugation to rhodamine-azide or biotin-azide (Figure 74). These chemical biology studies led to the identification of Trypanosoma brucei cdc2-like kinase 1 (TbCLK1) as the preferential target for hypothemycin.(208)

    Salinomycin-Derived Chemical Probe to Detect Subcellular Localization of Small Molecules

    Incubation of cells with an alkyne chemical probe 150 (ironomycin) and subsequent intracellular labeling of ironomycin using in situ click chemistry conditions and Alexa-Fluor 488-azide revealed the accumulation of the compound in lysosomal compartments (Figure 75). This result concluded that the target for ironomycin probe-precursor 149 (salinomycin) is lysosomes.(178)

    An Acetylene-Containing Natural Product Callysponginic Acid as a Chemical Probe for the Characterization of Potential Intracellular Targets
